Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.

content:
Today, June 28, is internationally known as Pride Day. This date was chosen as a reference to the Stonewall Inn riots, an episode remembered as a milestone in gay activism. Since that day, much progress has been done towards acceptance and inclusion of LGBTQIA+ people in many places around the world. In this post I want to highlight some contributions made by these people that allowed to world to become what it is today.
During my academic and professional life, few names were more cited than that of Alan Turing, the British mathematician known as “the father of modern computing”.
Born in June 23, 1912, Turing developed some thoughts on the similarities between a brain and a computer, establishing the idea of the brain as a “computing machine”.
One concept that is becoming mainstream in the era of Artificial Intelligente (AI) is that of a “thinking machine”. In his 1950 paper, “Computing machinery and intelligence”, Turing proposes that if a computer can provide answers in a way indistinguishable from how a human would perform in natural language conversation, than one could argue the this computes shows a kind of intelligent behavior. In his paper he uses the Imitation Game as starting point to his arguments. Interestingly, the movie “The Imitation game” (2014), an historical drama based on Turing’s life, barely mentions this idea, which is much better exploited in the movie “Ex-Machina” released the following year.
Besides his work on computational science, Turing is also credited for having decoded Enigma’s criptography. Enigma was a a machine used by the Nazis during the Second World War do send coded messages. Once the code was broken, the Allies could anticipate Axis’ moves and act accordingly. This episode is considered one of the war’s turning points.
However, all his contributions were not enough to save his life. Turing was homosexual, and on 1952 he was prosecuted for “gross indecency”. He had two options: 1. prison; 2. chemical castration. He chose the latter. He was found dead on 1954, victim cyanide poisoning. However, there are some divergences whether it was suicide or accidental poisoning.
It took almot 60 years to his condenation to be revisited. In 2013, Queen Elizabeth II granted Turing a posthumous pardon. It is said that his face will be printed on the £50 note as a recognition for his lifetime works.
Alan Turing’s life and influence in the past 50 years can be taken as an example of the presence and importance of LGBTQIA+ people in the world. Science and culture would not be so advanced or diverse or powerful if not by their work.
Although much as been done in the past years to ensure basic human rights, there is still so much to fight for. Let’s take this day as a celebration of our conquests and a reminder of the lives, sufferings and contributions of the ones that came before. May the Alan Turing’s of today and the future be able to live as they want, be who they are, and contribute to humanity’s growth, no matter their desires and aptitudes.
References Stonewall Riots - Wikipedia Turing, Alan (1950), Computing Machinery and Intelligence, Mind, LIX (236): 433–460. (link) The Imitation Game (IMDb) Ex-Machina (IMDb) Royal pardon for codebreaker Alan Turing - BBC Turing’s face on the pound note - The Guardian
summary: Some words on Pride Day. An example of importance and influence of LGBT people in our history
title: Alan Turing

content:
I finally decided to start writing on this website. It was something I wanted for a long time, but always delayed for multiple reasons. The start of the Coronavirus pandemic didn’t help at all… :-)
I hope to write every week about different subjects. Most of the posts will probably be some tutorials on Python, R, data science and software development as those are the things that keep me busy during the week. However, I might also write about human rights, education and research topics on neuroscience and physics.
For this first post I will present a small app I have been developing in the past few weeks.
In the beginning of this year I looked for data and information involving crimes against LGBT people in Brazil. It is said that we have one of the highest crime rates in the world1, but I wanted to see the raw data and maybe try to have some insights when studying time series and correlated events on this subject.
I tried to contact some people from Grupo Gay da Bahia but I have never received an answer. I talked to some friends and learned that crimes against LGBT people are rarely registered in official documents in a regular manner. I ended up rummaging the federal government website, notably the “Ministry of Family and Human Rights” but found only their promises of providing updated and open access data on human rights in Brazil. In a page that is no longer accessible, it is said that strategies to be adopted for the opening, support, monitoring and promotion of their database would be produced with deadline for August 2019.
In fact, I contacted them on February asking for an update on this issue (the deadline was past for about six months), but after two months of waiting they only said that “all necessary information, schedules and databases to be used will soon be published”. In other words: “we have been working for almost a year and still don’t have anything planned”.
Anyway, during my time clicking around the Ministry’s website I found that at least SOME information is public. The Brazilian government provides a help line (called “Disque Denúncia” or “Disque Direitos Humanos”2) so people can call and denounce domestic abuse, child and elderly maltreatment etc. Among the several profiles available, one can see calls coming from LGBT people. There is data from 2011 to 2019 (only partially, as this year’s data covers only until June).
I downloaded all data concerning LGBT people through this link. The data tables are actually very complete, but all data is just the case counts in multiple categories (sex, age, location…). Because of this I was not able to get any insights from it, but I decided to organize it to make it easier for people to look at some trends.
In order to do that, I developed a very simple Shiny application in R. You can see the result here (Portuguese only). Data is separated in tabs representing different complainant profiles. You can see how the cases increases or decreases for different Brazilian states in the past eight years.

 I thought I could update this application as new data was released. However, the Brazilian government changed how this information would be released. Their last report sum up the cases in a pdf file and one can’t access the raw data as I did. If the government decides to releases open data, I will develop a new app and try to provide some kind of easily accessible platform. Until then and without new data I think this app will be just a snapshot of complaints made by LGBT people by middle 2019.
All the data used in the development os this app can be found on my Github page (the code needs some cleaning…) and only exists thanks to projects like Shinyapps.io.
P.S.: I intend to write in English in this website, but I will probably translate the posts about this app as it concerns primarily the Brazilian LGBT population.
References https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Brazil#Anti-LGBT_violence https://www.gov.br/mdh/pt-br/acesso-a-informacao/ouvidoria/balanco-disque-100
summary: A Shiny app based on 'Disque Denúncia' database
title: Brazilian LGBT complaints in the past decade

summary: Neurons and cardiac cells are known to be susceptible to electromagnetic radiation. Although many mathematical models exist to represent these cells, only recently there was an effort to include the electromagnetic induction on the membrane potential equations. In this paper, we investigate the effects of the induction on the logistic KTz, a computationally efficient map-based action potential model, and compare them to the more widely used Hindmarsh–Rose model. We study the effects of a self-induced current on a single cell and the synchronization of cells coupled through an induction current caused by the magnetic flux of the neighbor. We also study the emergence of aperiodic behaviors and the presence of chaos, as an effect of the inclusion of the induction. Besides, we use a simple network of KTz elements to show that the electromagnetic induction is relevant for the study of pattern formation. Additionally, we report for the first time the presence of cardiac spikes in the Hindmarsh–Rose model. Our results demonstrate the importance of implementing the induction current on different models and we provide a computationally efficient alternative to better understand how the induction acts on neuronal and cardiac cells.
title: Electromagnetic induction on a map-based action potential model

summary: We introduce a new map-based neuron model derived from the dynamical perceptron family that has the best compromise between computational efficiency, analytical tractability, reduced parameter space and many dynamical behaviors. We calculate bifurcation and phase diagrams analytically and computationally that underpins a rich repertoire of autonomous and excitable dynamical behaviors. We report the existence of a new regime of cardiac spikes corresponding to nonchaotic aperiodic behavior. We compare the features of our model to standard neuron models currently available in the literature.
title: Phase diagrams and dynamics of a computationally efficient map-based neuron model

summary: Activity in the brain propagates as waves of firing neurons, namely avalanches. These waves’ size and duration distributions have been experimentally shown to display a stable power-law profile, long-range correlations and $1/f^b$ power spectrum in vivo and in vitro. We study an avalanching biologically motivated model of mammals visual cortex and find an extended critical-like region – a Griffiths phase – characterized by divergent susceptibility and zero order parameter. This phase lies close to the expected experimental value of the excitatory postsynaptic potential in the cortex suggesting that critical be-havior may be found in the visual system. Avalanches are not perfectly power-law distributed, but it is possible to collapse the distributions and define a cutoff avalanche size that diverges as the network size is increased inside the critical region. The avalanches present long-range correlations and $1/f^b$ power spectrum, matching experiments. The phase transition is analytically determined by a mean-field approximation.
title: Griffiths phase and long-range correlations in a biologically motivated visual cortex model

summary: We study a new biologically motivated model for the Macaque monkey primary visual cortex which presents power-law avalanches after a visual stimulus. The signal propagates through all the layers of the model via avalanches that depend on network structure and synaptic parameter. We identify four different avalanche profiles as a function of the excitatory postsynaptic potential. The avalanches follow a size-duration scaling relation and present critical exponents that match experiments. The structure of the network gives rise to a regime of two characteristic spatial scales, one of which vanishes in the thermodynamic limit.
title: Information processing occurs via critical avalanches in a model of the primary visual cortex

summary: All sky cameras are a great alternative to the study of atmospheric conditions in an astronomical site. We show how to compute the instantaneous coefficients of atmospheric extinction for various moments in the same night. The images used were obtained by the camera SASCA (SOAR AllSky Camera) located at Cerro Pachon. To estimate the extinction coefficients we developed a method to measure the brightness of several stars at different air masses for the same instant. We developed a Python program that calculates azimuth and altitude for the stars and then converts them to pixel coordinates on the CCD. Comparing the positions calculated for a group of stars with their actual positions on the images, we can determine the distortion caused by the camera. After finding out the distortions we know exactly in which pixel a star falls on any date and time. At this point we created tables of star positions and did the photometry of them all on each image using the IRAF routine PHOT. These photometry tables are subsequently converted into multiple tables with apparent magnitude versus air mass for each star at a given instant. Our results show that the extinction coefficient calculated for different atmospheric moments is within two sigma of the values of the coefficients obtained through the monitoring of a single star at different air masses, demonstrating the feasibility of our approach.
title: Extinction coefficients with an allsky camera
